PrerequisitesInstalling services requires that the HDP Installer 2.0, also known as HDPI, has already been installed.
The images for the individual services will be downloaded when the service installation is started. A separate download step is not necessary.
The installer retrieves service configuration information from the clouds.yaml file. If you did not create a clouds.yaml file earlier, you can create one now.

section.title: Configure Availability Zones
section.p: To configure the Database Service in a highly available manner, it is necessary to create separate availability zones. As a best practice, HPE recommends creating three availability zones. All hosts should be placed within one of these availability zones.

If a host is not associated with an availability zone, the Database Service will not be able to provision a database instance to it. As a result, the Database Service may run out of capacity even though there are hosts with free capacity.
The following steps show how to create three availability zones and assign a compute host to the zone.

ol.li: Execute the following commands to create three availability zones named: "AZ-1", "AZ-2" and "AZ-3".openstack aggregate create --zone AZ-1 aggregate-AZ-1 openstack aggregate create --zone AZ-2 aggregate-AZ-2 openstack aggregate create --zone AZ-3 aggregate-AZ-3
Validate that the availability zones were correctly created by issuing the following command.openstack aggregate list

The following commands will add a host to your newly created aggregate. Execute this command once for every host that you wish to associate with an aggregate.openstack aggregate add host <aggregate name or id> <host>
The following command can be used to list all availability zones and the hosts associated with each one.openstack availability zone list

In addition to the quotas mentioned above, for every database instance that is created by a user, the necessary resources to create that instance will be deducted from the admin project quota. The user's database service quota will also be affected.

ol.li:
Source a stack RC file for the admin user and project.
Log in to Horizon using the admin account.
Download the OpenStack RC file.
Use scp to copy the RC file over to the Deployer.
SSH to the Deployer and source the RC file. You will need to provide the same admin password that you used to log in to Horizon.
source admin-openrc.sh
The installer retrieves service configuration information from the clouds.yaml file. If you did not create a clouds.yaml file earlier, you must create one now.
List the available database versions to install: openstack hdpi list --os-cloud mycloud | grep database The output should look similar to:database | wscatalog.2655 | 2.0.0.0 | available
Select the database version to install and view the details of the package:openstack hdpi show wscatalog.2655 --os-cloud mycloud

Install the database service openstack --os-cloud mycloud hdpi database install --package wscatalog.2655 The output will appear similar to: $ os hdpi als install --package wscatalog.1985 Database is now downloading ... ... Database is (downloaded) Database is already (available) Database is already configured Launching stack... Stack trove creating Completed installing database $

section.sectiondiv:
Configure HAProxyThe following steps will configure HAProxy to receive and forward HTTP requests to the VM that hosts the REST API endpoint for the Database Service.
Identify the API server IPs on the SVC network. You should have as many API servers (and IPs) as you have Availability Zones in your HPE Helion OpenStack installation.
openstack server list | awk '/trove[0-9]*_api/{ print $4,"\t", substr($8,5) }'
Identify the Virtual IP used to load balance the HPE Helion OpenStack services:openstack endpoint show database -c publicurl --format value
Update configuration on each of the HPE Helion OpenStack controller nodes by connecting to the controller and doing the following:
Edit the /etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg file and add the following lines. The last line should be repeated once for each API server identified in step 1.listen trove_api bind <virtual IP from step 2>:8779 option httpchk GET / server trove-trove<n>_api-<uniqueid> <API server n's IP Address> check inter 2000 rise 2 fall 5
Run the following command as root:sudo iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 8779 -j ACCEPT
Reload the haproxy service configurationsudo service haproxy reload
The installation is complete. Return to the Horizon dashboard (you may log out and log in with a non-Admin account if desired), and click on the Database panel under the current Project to begin using the Database Service.
